metadata.synopsis: James Bond (Roger Moore) may have met his match in Octopussy (Maud Adams), an entrancing beauty involved in a devastating military plot to destroy détente. From the palaces of India to a speeding circus train in Germany and a mid-air battle on the wing of a high-flying jet, only Agent 007 can stop the nightmarish scheme!

reviews: It's an easy film to hate (and often paints a big target on its back encouraging you to do so), but it works perfectly as a piece of entertainment, where the good ultimately outweighs the bad.
For the first time in the series, the story unfolds like a true mystery, instead of merely having some eccentric billionaire devising a plot to take over the world.
Out of all the Roger Moore films as Bond, this one is easily the worse for me.
The naffness that was prevalent in the Bond series around the time of Moore still abounds here.
The very worst Roger Moore Bond Film, and one to avoid unless you really have to watch every single film in a marathon, like myself, sadly...
"Octopussy" is the 13th of the James Bond movies, and it is one of the best.
Considering Bond gets disguised as an ape, a crocodile and a clown, the film has a lot more to be embarrassed about than its title.
It's a pleasure to report that the James Bond company is confidently back on the beam.
This was the 13th Bond movie and it's possibly the most frivolous in the series to date (it's certainly the most careless).
[Director John Glen] keeps the excitement level high for an hour or so, then lets the show slip into the doldrums.
A solid action movie without the variety show camp of Moonraker, Octopussy (shock, horror) may well the best of the Moores.
While this film is not up to the level of Goldfinger or Live and Let Die, it is still first-class escapist entertainment.
More sexual innuendo than usual in provocatively named film.
Octopussy features 2 stand-out action sequences but for the most part, it's an overlong, sluggish, and schizophrenic entry in the Bond series.

James Bond is old. Wrinkled-forehead old. Lecherous-coot old. Strategic-hairstyle old. Senior meal-discount old. Simply ... old. That's the biggest takeaway from Roger Moore's second-worst outing as 007, hot on the heels of his second-best.
While the film is the first of the genuinely bloated Bond movies, it only rarely drags.
Bottom-drawer Bond.

Glen's willingness to give the action sequences a certain weight and seriousness produces some genuinely exciting moments, yet his work is everywhere undermined by the flatness of the characterizations and the uncertain architecture of the plot.
Little is added that departs from the Bond formula.
Film's high points are the spectaccular aerial stuntwork marking both the pre-credits teaser and extremely dangerous-looking climax.
